description: From Late Middle English schrille, shirle, shrille (“of a sound: high-pitched, piercing; producing such a sound”), possibly from the earlier shil, schille (“loud, resounding; high-pitched, shrill; audible, clear; melodious, sweet-sounding”), from Old English scill (“sonorous sounding”), of Germanic origin. The r in the word was introduced by analogy to Middle English skrīke, skrīken, scrēmen, possibly to avoid confusion with non-Anglian forms of schelle (modern English shell) where Old English scill (“sonorous sounding”) and scill (“shell”) existed.
The word is cognate with Icelandic skella (“crash, bang, slam”), Low German schrell (“sharp in taste or tone”).

examples: The woods rang with shrill cries of the birds.

entries.meaning: Sharp or keen to the senses.
(figuratively, derogatory, especially of a complaint or demand) Fierce, loud, strident.

verbs.description: shrill (third-person singular simple present shrills, present participle shrilling, simple past and past participle shrilled)
